title: The Best of the Bayou in Chicago
text:
The Best of the Bayou in Chicago Authentic Louisiana Cuisine Spices Up Windy City Heaven on Seven's spicy fried shrimp. Photo courtesy of Heaven on Seven By Audarshia Townsend Updated February 21, 2017 . 
Think again if you believe you cannot get authentic Louisiana cuisine in Chicago. From chef-driven fare that takes Cajun and Creole cooking to an entirely different level to one of the biggest Sunday brunch buffets in town, here are our favorites to let the good times roll. 
Big Jones . Though you'll also find Carolina Lowcountry cuisine on the menu at this popular Andersonville eatery, Big Jones focuses mostly on food from the Gulf Coast and Louisiana. Owner/chef Paul Fehribach takes pride in learning the history of the cuisine and cocktails, and he hosts frequent dinners in which he explores their deep, Southern roots. Standard menu items include gumbo, shrimp and grits, chicken and dumplings, and sweet tea-brined pork loin. A carefully curated cocktail menu complements the cuisine by paying homage to classic Southern sippers like the Sazerac . 5347 N. Clark St., 773-275-5725 
Frontier .New Orleans native Brian Jupiter gleefully puts a chef-driven spin on classic Creole cuisine at this Wicker Park favorite that's only eight minutes from downtown. 
continue reading below our video America's Best Foodie Cities The menu is very wild-game friendly, with such offbeat dishes like pulled boar sandwiches, BBQ rabbit leg and alligator scallopini. Jupiter's brunch menu is equally Southern focused, with a number of rich, flavorful dishes such as beignets topped with rum apple sauce, char-grilled oysters, fried rabbit and waffles, and crab Benedict made with fresh blue crab, roasted tomato, scallions, a poached egg and cayenne Hollandaise. 1072 N. Milwaukee Ave., 773-772-4322 
Heaven on Seven . Jimmy Bannos Sr.'s kitschy, New Orleans-themed restaurant in the Loop has been cranking for more than 30 years. It offers a smattering of classic dishes to complement its permanent Mardi Gras decor. Highlights include a number of options for Po'Boy sandwiches, Hoppin' John with Andouille sausage, and jambalaya. During Mardi Gras season, the restaurant hosts a number of events that include live music. 111 N. Wabash Ave., 312-263-6443 
House of Blues . Guests who visit the first-floor Crossroads in the evening--when there is live music nightly--must order dinner or a two-drink minimum. Menu staples include cornbread with maple syrup, plus shrimp and grits, buttermilk fried chicken, pulled pork sliders, gumbo, jambalaya and bourbon bread pudding. The House of Blues' music hall is also the setting for the weekly Gospel Brunch , which spotlights well-known gospel singers such as Kirk Franklin . The buffet-style event offers Southern cuisine favorites like fried chicken, mashed potatoes, peel-and-eat shrimp and turnip greens. 329 N. Dearborn St., 312-923-2000 
Lafayette . Those patronizing the West Loop 's Chicago French Market can get a taste of the Bayou at this tiny restaurant serving breakfast through dinner. The menu is limited, but offers tasty choices such as Po'Boys, gumbo and jambalaya. It's in close proximity to the Amtrak station as well as a number of hotels. 131 N. Clinton St., 312-207-6225 
Luellaâ€™s Southern Kitchen . The Lincoln Square-based eatery was named in honor of chef/owner Darnell Reed's great-grandmother--whose delicious Southern recipes inspired him to pursue his passion for cooking as a career. Expect contemporary updates to classic dishes like braised short rib mac and cheese, bourbon-infused chicken and waffles, BBQ shrimp and grits, and a fried green tomato BLT. The restaurant is BYOB; no corkage fee required. 4609 N. Lincoln Ave., 773-961-8196 
Wishbone . Known as a favorite of Oprah when she lived in Chicago, the West Loop location for the Southern-themed eatery continues to be hit with area residents and workers. Among the top sellers includes crawfish cakes, jambalaya Cajun stew and blackened catfish tacos. The famous muffins--which arrive piping hot with every entree--are stuffed with bits of corn. 1001 W. Washington Blvd., 312-850-2663
